awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2017 ACM Conference on Information and Knowledge Management  (CIKM)
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation award funds Student Travel Fellowships for US students attending CIKM 2017, the 2017 ACM International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management, which brings together researchers and practitioners from the knowledge management, information retrieval, and database communities. The Student Fellowships help cover the travel costs for US students, enabling them to participate in CIKM and interact with other attendees of the conference.

Through the publication, presentation, and discussion of applied and theoretical research findings, CIKM attendees shape the future by identifying challenging problems facing the creation of advanced knowledge and information systems, and by providing insightful solution approaches for those problems. CIKM 2017 has broad and interdisciplinary programs including workshops, tutorials, industry speakers, keynote speakers, research papers and posters, demonstrations, competitions, and other special events.  Students will also benefit from activities designed especially to appeal to them, including a Hackathon, an Industry Networking Day; a resume circulation service; and three data analytics competitions.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This NSF Student Travel Grant supported the travel of 21 students from US universities to attend the Conference for Information and Knowledge Management (CIKM) 2017 in Singapore, as well as the travel of 18 students from US universities to attend CIKM 2018 in Turin, Italy. Applications were accepted from full-time students at degree granting institutions. All student participants were eligible to apply for awards, including students presenting regular papers, posters, demonstrations, and those participating in workshops or the AnalytiCup competition.

The selection process for the awards was competitive; members of underrepresented groups were given priority in the evaluation of applications, along with the student authors of accepted papers and competition finalists.

At CIKM, the award recipients presented and learned about cutting-edge research results in knowledge management, information retrieval, and data management. The award recipients were able to attend three keynote presentations by we ll known researchers and participate in hands-on tutorials, traditional tutorials, and workshops.  In addition, award recipients were able to interact with the authors of hundreds of research papers and demos, selected from over 1000 submissions in 2017 and over 1500 submissions in 2018. By engaging with the scientific community in their area of specialty, the award recipients came one step closer to becoming full-fledged contributors to that community.

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2019
Modified by: Marianne Winslett

Applications were accepted from full-time students at degree granting   institutions.  All student participants were eligible to apply for   awards, including   students presenting regular papers, posters,   demonstrations, and those   participating in workshops or the AnalytiCup   competition.

The selection process for the awards was   competitive; members of  underrepresented groups were given priority in   the evaluation of  applications, along with the student authors of  accepted  papers and  competition finalists.

At CIKM, the award  recipients presented and learned about  cutting-edge research results in  knowledge management, information  retrieval, and data management. The award recipients were able to attend  three keynote presentations by we ll known researchers and participate  in hands-on tutorials, traditional tutorials, and workshops.  In  addition, award recipients were able to interact with the authors of  hundreds of research papers and demos, selected from over 1000  submissions in 2017 and over 1500 submissions in 2018. By  engaging with  the scientific community in their area of specialty, the  award  recipients came one step closer to becoming full-fledged  contributors  to that community.
